nodes.name: Exploitability of AI agents by predictors or blackmailers in Newcomblike dilemmas
nodes.description: Risk that AI systems systematically forfeit large utility or pay extortion when facing entities that can accurately predict or model their behavior (e.g., Newcomb’s problem, XOR or mechanical blackmail).
nodes.node_rationale: Highlighted across Sections 2, 4, 6 and 9 as the main negative consequence of using CDT/EDT.

nodes.name: Overconditioning on evidential correlations in evidential decision theory
nodes.description: Problem where EDT treats mere statistical correlations between its action and world events as if they were controllable, leading to ‘managing the news’, paying blackmail, and refusing beneficial information.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in Sections 2, 7 and the XOR blackmail example as primary mechanism causing exploitability.

nodes.name: Ignoring logical dependencies in causal decision theory
nodes.description: Problem where CDT severs logical links between its action and accurate predictions about that action, yielding dominated choices, instability and vulnerability (e.g., Death in Damascus).
nodes.node_rationale: Explained in Sections 3, 8 and multiple dilemmas as the CDT-specific failure mode.

nodes.name: Subjunctive dependence distinguishes causal, logical, and statistical relations in decision-making
nodes.description: Insight that events can depend on an agent’s decision function output even without causal influence; correct hypotheticals must keep such dependencies aligned while allowing statistical ones to break.
nodes.node_rationale: Core idea introduced in Section 3 Subjunctive Dependence; underpins FDT.

nodes.name: Decision-making centered on outputs of fixed decision function in functional decision theory
nodes.description: Design principle: an agent evaluates ‘Which output of this very decision procedure leads to best outcomes?’ rather than evaluating physical acts directly, aligning all logically dependent processes.
nodes.node_rationale: Explained in Overview and Section 5; forms the solution concept derived from the theoretical insight.

nodes.name: Graphical do-intervention on decision function variable for FDT reasoning
nodes.description: Implementation mechanism where an agent represents its world model as a graph and performs Pearl-style do(·) interventions not on the action node but on the node representing FDT’s logical output.
nodes.node_rationale: Formally detailed in Section 5 Formalizing EDT, CDT, and FDT.

nodes.name: FDT outperforms CDT and EDT across canonical dilemmas
nodes.description: Validation evidence: FDT one-boxes and smokes (Sections 2 & 6), pays driver in Parfit’s hitchhiker (Section 4), resists XOR/mechanical blackmail (Sections 7 & 9) and avoids Death-in-Damascus instability (Section 8), yielding higher expected utility.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 6 Comparison and later sections quantify utility advantages.

nodes.name: Integrate functional decision theory into AI agent decision module during design
nodes.description: At model-design time, implement the FDT algorithm—reasoning over decision-function outputs with subjunctive dependency graphs—in place of CDT/EDT to harden agents against predictor exploitation, blackmail and coordination failures.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Proposed throughout paper as a theory-level replacement for existing decision modules; corresponds to design-phase choice (Introduction & Conclusion).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Currently theoretical with proof-of-concept toy-problem validation (Sections 5 & 6); no large-scale deployment yet.
nodes.node_rationale: Represents actionable takeaway for AI safety practitioners—directly derived from paper’s conclusion.
